children.subject:
Not putting in student response bc haven't taken 126 or the upperdivs (so someone else could offer more insight) but I have taken Stat 133, Stat 140, CS70, (and will take 135 in fall). 

I advise you to contact the professors of 153 of 151a or comb through the syllabi with more detail. 

EE 126 (from what I understand in syllabi) deals a lot with probability and its theory. If any upperdiv stat course required a background in probability, then ee126 would probably suffice.

However, Stat 135 is not a probability course at heart (that is stat 134/140). Stat 135 is about the fundamentals of statistical theory and methods, such as hypothesis tests, estimation, bootstraping, etc. If the upperdivs require that portion of the course, then I don't believe 126 is the proper prereq.

history.content: Allow me to comment on taking Stat 153 given a background in probability theory (CS70, EE126, Stat 134), without a concrete background in statistics. I took Stat 153 this previous semester. First, from the perspective of getting a good grade, you will have to adapt slightly to the way the Stat department does things, especially in exam styles, but this should not be the main consideration or hinderance, and if your aim is to get a good grade then the given background is more than sufficient. Now, onto the perspective of getting the most out of the course: The biggest thing you are lacking not having taken Stat 135 is a lot of the basic terminology and the way of thinking of stats people. Amongst these is working knowledge of confidence intervals, hypothesis and significance tests, errors in estimation, and bootstrapping. The big benefit you have on your side is that all these topics are covered very cursorily in Stat 135 (from my understanding) and it is not till Stat 210A that the theory behind these ideas is covered at all. If you have invested time and effort into EE126, then you have (probably) adapted to a (semi) theoretical way of approaching problems, and this allows you to pick up these topics a beforehand from a well-suited textbook, and be able to follow along the course of your choice (say 153) well. However, do note that it is key that you pick up working knowledge in these topics as you go along, because without that you might get a good grade in the class, but miss out on many key takeaways that the course can offer you (for example: when forecasting using ARIMA models, what methods are most useful for which specific cases and so on). Further, this means that you will have more work than the rest of the class (however, I will point out that in my (perhaps biased) opinion, the workload in this class was substantially lesser than EE126: 6 assignments of 5-6 small questions, and 1 project). Now, finally, the specific subject matter of Stat 153 (time series analysis) is supplemental to statistical courses, and you do not need anything specific to prepare for it - only for the application of this subject matter using statistical principles.

children.subject: I think if you have taken EECS126 and want to get into ML, then taking EE127 followed by EECS189 is the standard recommended path. This will expose you to a lot of modules within the broad umbrella of machine learning, and then you can pick specialty courses to take depending on your interest. Having done all of this, the material in STAT151A that isn't covered is mostly self-studyable. Taking STAT 153 is still recommended, but you want to pick an instructor carefully, as that will make or break your experience. Finally, ensure that if you do take STAT153, take it to get exposure to the statistical lens of looking at problems, and let that (along with statistical terminology) be your key takeaway from the course.
Thanks! I have heard from others that there is some similarity between EE120 and Stat 153. Which one do you recommend?

I took Stat 153 having already taken EE120. Right off the bat, I think that is the appropriate sequence to take them in if you have the background assumed in this thread. The two are not alternatives to each other, and have a lot of content aside from the overlapping material (for the large part, the overlap is restricted to the spectral analysis of signals and time indexed data). I highly recommend taking them both, and in this sequence. In that case, first taking EE120 gives you the EE perspective on signal processing. Note, EE120 has a lot more than just frequency analysis of signals (Eg: Llinear system theory, for starters). Now, Stat 153 also has a lot more than the spectral analysis of signals (Eg: ARIMA modeling, GARCH models, forecasting and a lot more). Further, even the part which overlaps is handled differently in both the courses: 120 looks at it from a signals point of view, and Stat 153 gives some very nice insights from a statisticians point of view (for instance: how the Fourier transform is an ANOVA splitting the variance into frequency components).
Hey Nikunj, would you suggestion 153 over 151A? Which one do you think it's more useful for ML. I am also planning to take EE127, so no sure how useful 151A will be.

history.content: How hard would it be to take stat 153 or 151a after taking ee 126 but not stat 135 (listed as prereq)?
